prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for making their girlfriend start paying some bills after a single incident where she was upset about paying for takeout.

First, the situation: They live together. The author pays all the bills, the girlfriend works part-time. The incident was the author forgetting his wallet and asking her to pay for $40 takeout. Her reaction was negative—disgusted tone, acting put out. Now the author wants her to start contributing, partly out of principle.

Hmm. So, the author is upset because of her reaction to one incident. The key points here are about fairness, communication, and expectations in a relationship. 

The author pays all the bills. The girlfriend's part-time job might mean she has less income, but maybe she does contribute in other ways (like chores, taking care of the home, etc.). The author is now holding one incident where the girlfriend was upset as justification for changing the financial arrangement. 

Is the author in the wrong? Well, using a single incident to change the financial dynamics might be disproportionate. Relationships require mutual support and communication. The author didn't consider if there were underlying issues with their financial arrangement before. Maybe the girlfriend feels taken for granted, even if she isn't paying in cash. The author is reacting emotionally to her negative reaction without addressing the broader context. 

Also, expecting someone to contribute based on a single event without discussing it could be unfair. The author is making a big change (asking her to pay bills) over a relatively small amount ($40) and a one-time occurrence. It seems like the author is using this incident as a catalyst for a change they've been thinking about, but maybe didn't have the right conversation first. 

In relationships, it's important to have open communication about finances and expectations. Instead of using a single incident to enforce a change, discussing how they both feel about financial responsibilities would be better. The author might be in the wrong because they're reacting impulsively rather than addressing the issue with consideration for their partner's situation and feelings.
